Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Tropical Forest Mobility and Subsistence

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Under the direction of Dr. Michael E. Smith of Arizona State University, Mr. Timothy Dennehy, will conduct research to address a central anthropological question: how do human societies change as they transition from foraging to agriculture? The origin of agriculture is one of the most heavily researched topics in the study of human prehistory, and much is known about the first people to independently adopt farming in each area of the world. Yet comparatively little is known about the pre-agricultural groups that occupied these same landscapes before farming arose. This hampers understanding of both domestication processes as well as the changes to human society that accompanied them. By analyzing multiple lines of evidence derived from the stone artifacts (lithics) from three sites in the Lowland Maya region of Mesoamerica, this project will contribute greatly to understanding of how human groups transition from a mobile hunting and gathering lifestyle to a more sedentary one focused on food production. This project also works cooperatively with descendant Maya communities in Belize, thus contributing to the training and education of an ethnic group underrepresented in the STEM fields.

Mr. Dennehy will examine how tropical forest foragers changed their mobility strategies over time in response to an environment that they themselves were altering through their manipulation of forest resources. The term "mobility strategy" here refers to the number of moves made by a group in a given year. On one end of the spectrum, a Residential Mobility Strategy entails many small moves in which the entire group sets up a new camp every few days. On the other end, a Logistical Mobility Strategy entails fewer residential moves but a greater number of small task-oriented (i.e. logistical) moves, wherein specialized groups of foragers undertake long-range trips to bring vital resources back to a central camp. Modern-day tropical forest groups that rely solely on wild resources tend to practice the former strategy; other modern-day groups who more extensively manipulate their environments and cultivate resources tend practice the latter. These two mobility strategies affect the amount of raw material available for stone tool production; in turn, raw material availability impacts several lithic traits, making this project's lithic analysis one of the only ways to indirectly assess mobility strategies. The rockshelters that are the focus of this study contain deposits that date from 8000-900 B.C., and cover the late Paleoindian/Early Archaic transition through the Late Archaic/Middle Preclassic transition, a record whose time-depth and completeness is unparalleled in the Maya world. This record is anchored at one end by the early hunter-gatherer societies who preceded domestication, and on the other by fully agricultural Maya groups; thus, it will provide evidence of the full spectrum of subsistence strategies utilized during the transition from foraging to agriculture. By examining mobility and subsistence throughout this long time period and at three different locations, this study offers a unique spatio-temporal perspective on changing Mesoamerican foraging societies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
My dissertation research project examines changes in hunter-gatherer lifeways in ancient tropical forest ecosystems. Specifically, it analyzes the interplay between hunter-gatherer mobility, stone tool (lithic) technology, subsistence, and changes in climate and ecology during a transitional, dynamic period. My research focuses on lithic assemblages from three rockshelters in southern Belize, part of what would eventually become the Maya Lowlands. These rockshelters were used intensively by humans from the Late Pleistocene up until the Classic Maya period, and so contain over ten millennia-worth of records of human occupation.

By analyzing lithic artifacts from these shelters, I was able to characterize the lithic technology of their occupants as either curated or expedient. The first term (curated) refers to the propensity to spend more time and effort in shaping a formal stone tool, and to keep it for longer periods of time, resharpening and reshaping it as necessary. The second term (expedient) refers to the opposite trend: spending little time or effort to prepare and create an informal tool, and actively using it for a shorter length of time. The ethnographic record of modern-day hunter gatherers indicates that curated lithics tend to be favored by highly mobile groups focused more on animal resources than plants, while expedient lithics are associated with more sedentary foragers who spend more time and effort manipulating plant resources in their environment. It is just this type of manipulation that gave rise to early cultivars - that is,  ancestors of today's domesticated crops like corn - so providing a better sense of the timing of this transition is important to understanding the origins of agriculture.

After examining several lithic traits related to expedient or curated technology, I found that the first foragers to occupy the shelters around 12,0000 years ago were likely highly mobile big-game hunters who were still somewhat new to the region, and who inhabited a much drier, cooler landscape than that of today. Later, during the Early Holocene period (10,000 to 8,000 years ago), the climate began a change that would last several millennia, slowly becoming both warmer and wetter throughout the region, while tropical rainforests began to dominate the landscape. During this early period, lithic assemblages show a slow decline in the types of formal bifacial tools used in hunting large game, and a switch to less formal, more expedient tool types. Later still, during the Middle Holocene (8,000 to 4,000 years ago), climatic records show a peak in warmth and precipitation, coupled with a complete change to closed-canopy tropical rainforest. Duriung this period, the decline in curated, formal tools continued, while more expedient types predominate. Finally, during the Late Holocene (after 4000 years ago), expedient tool types reach their greatest frequency, indicating the greatest level of sedentism experienced by foragers who were beginning to become farmers. Based on my research, this transition appears to occur well before the first sedentary, ceramic-bearing villages were founded in the Maya Lowlands by people who we today call the ancient Maya.

Overall, my research shows that people in this region began transitioning to a more sedentary lifestyle focused on plant manipulation much earlier than most Maya archaeologists generally think. However, this earlier date of transition does match up with reported early dates for the first domestication of corn, manioc, and other important cultivars. These early crops were quite different than those we see today, and were likely only a smart part of the diet during these initial phases of domestication. Moreover, an early, more gradual transition to a sedentary, plant-using lifestyle has far-reaching implications for our understanding of several important archaeologial topics, including: the adoption of agriculture; the founding of permanent, sedentary villages; and the geographic and cultural origins of the peoples who would become the ancient Maya. It also has implications for the descendants of those people who today occupy small villages throughout southern Belize. By bringing to light the even greater antiquity of the occupation of the Maya Lowlands by semi-sedentary forager-cultivators, my research strengthens the claims made by these Maya-speaking descent groups to ownership and autonomy in their communities. This autonomy is currently threatened by political and corporate interests in the region who seek to use the landscape for other purposes. These threats have sparked a resurgence of interest in Mayan language, culture, and prehistory amongst people in the region. I plan to share the results of my research via Mayan-language radio and English-language articles, and so hope to contribute to the growing recognition of modern-day Mayan peoples' ancient ties to the land of their ancestors.
